curam.util.client.domain.defaults

Interface DomainDefault

  • All Superinterfaces:
    DomainPlugIn, PlugIn
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractDefault, CodeTableCodeDefault, SvrBlobDefault, SvrBooleanDefault, SvrCharDefault, SvrDateDefault, SvrDateTimeDefault, SvrDateTimeDefaultCurrTime, SvrDoubleDefault, SvrFloatDefault, SvrInt16Default, SvrInt32Default, SvrInt64Default, SvrInt8Default, SvrMoneyDefault, SvrStringDefault

    public interface DomainDefault
extends DomainPlugIn

    An interface for domain plug-ins that can provide the default value of a domain for use when no value is entered on a form by a user or when no value is available to initialize an input field displayed on a form.

    Each domain has a corresponding Java data-type that is used to when storing values that are within that domain. For example, the SVR_INT32 domain and all of its descendant domains are stored using the java.lang.Integer class. Instances of these Java class are passed to and from the application server at run-time and the instances may never be null.

    When a user enters data on a page and submits it, all of the values are received as character strings, so it is necessary to convert these strings to the appropriate Java data-type for the domain. This is performed by the DomainConverter.parse(java.lang.String) method. However, if the user has not entered values into all of the fields on the form, then some of the character string values will be empty or null. As classes such as java.lang.Integer cannot represent "no value" and a null value is not permitted, a default value must be assumed.

    Another need for default values arises when a form is presented to a user and some of the fields have no source value available to initialize them. The default behavior (though it can be overridden using the USE_DEFAULT attribute of the UIM FIELD element) is to display a default value in the field on the form that is appropriate for the domain. For example, fields for the input of numeric values will be initialized to zero and those for dates will be initialized to the current date. Unless specifically overridden, the default values used will be the same as those used when processing empty form fields. The default value used for this field initialization can be overridden by setting the domain definition's "default" option in the UML model. However, this "displayed default value" is not applied when empty form fields are processed, the normal "assumed default value" is applied in that case.

    To illustrate this, say that a domain called PAYMENT is created in the UML model. It is a sub-domain of the core domain SVR_MONEY, a numeric domain and its "default" option is set to "100.00". A user opens a form page to enter a new value in a field that targets a property declared with the PAYMENT domain, but there is no source value to initialize that field. The client infrastructure will automatically initialize the field to "100.00", because that is the default value specified in the model. However, if the user clears the contents of the field and submits the form, the default value "0.00" will be applied, because that is the default value assumed for SVR_MONEY and all of its sub-domains when no value is entered. This behavior is what users expect, as they cannot know that clearing a field means the value is "100.00" unless they are familiar with the UML model and the domain definition options.

    There is a distinction, therefore, between a default value that is assumed when empty fields on a form are submitted and a default value that is displayed when fields on a form have no initial value available. This interface defines a domain plug-in that can provide either of these values.

    Classes that implement this plug-in can be associated with domains to provide the assumed default value. All of the defaults for the core domains are already provided, and these defaults are inherited by sub-domains, so it is unlikely that you will need to override the default behavior. If you need to set a different assumed default value, you can extend one of the core domain default classes and configure the plug-in as normal.

    Most displayed default values can be defined in the UML model using the domain definition's "default" option. The classes that implement this plug-in will automatically return that value and fall-back to the assumed default value for the domain if it is not available. It is only for more dynamic values that new default value plug-in may need to be written. For example, the "out-of-the-box" default value plug-in for date and date-time domains will return the current date or date-time as the displayed default value if no value was specified in the UML model, but the assumed default value will be the "zero date".

    This interface should not be implemented directly. Instead, custom plug-in classes should extend an existing default value plug-in implementation or extend the curam.util.client.domain.defaults.AbstractDefault class.

    All of the methods have access to the locale and the domain information via the PlugIn.getLocale() and DomainPlugIn.getDomain() methods respectively.

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      static java.lang.String PLUG_IN_NAME
      The name of this type of domain plug-in.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Abstract Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      java.lang.Object getAssumedDefault()
      Gets the default value that will be assumed when a user clears a field on a form and submits no value.
      java.lang.Object getDisplayedDefault()
      Gets the default value that should be displayed when an input field has no initial value to display.

    • Field Detail

      • PLUG_IN_NAME

        static final java.lang.String PLUG_IN_NAME
        The name of this type of domain plug-in.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

    • Method Detail

      • getAssumedDefault

        java.lang.Object getAssumedDefault()
                            throws DomainException
        Gets the default value that will be assumed when a user clears a field on a form and submits no value. This value is represented using the appropriate Java data-type and is independent of the user's locale or preferences.
        Returns:
        An object representing the assumed default value for a domain; must not be null.
        Throws:
        DomainException - If there is a problem getting the default value.

      • getDisplayedDefault

        java.lang.Object getDisplayedDefault()
                              throws DomainException
        Gets the default value that should be displayed when an input field has no initial value to display. Individual fields can disable the display of this default value if needed. This value is represented using the appropriate Java data-type and is independent of the user's locale or preferences. Where possible, the implementation will use the default value defined in the domain definition's options in the UML model. If that value is not defined in the model, then the assumed default value may be used, or the implementation can use another appropriate value (e.g., the current date for a date domain).
        Returns:
        An object representing the displayed default value for a domain; must not be null.
        Throws:
        DomainException - If there is a problem getting the default value.
